comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content: This photo was presumably taken after September, 1887. The crew was rescued and arrived in port on September 21, 1887. They had been castaway for six months. Details of the wreck available in the Encyclopedia of Australian Shipwrecks. The raft made from wreckage by survivors is at the Southland Museum The boatshed created afterward for shipwrecked sailors still exists.

comment.author: 32741315@N06
comment._content:
Thanks so much for that info roketpad, it adds a lot to the photo. I'll pass it on to our curators.

Courtney
comment.authorname: National Library NZ on The Commons

comment.author: 32967294@N05
comment._content:
This might also help

From the Timaru Herald 3 November 1888
The Cruise of the Stella
Interesting Relics of the Derry Castle
The Stella arrived this morning from her annual cruise of the Snares, Campbell,Auckland,Antipodes,and Bounty Islands. Captain Fairchild found the provisions depot at the islands intact. He found the beach at the Auckland Islands strewn with relics of the ill-fated Derry Castle. The figurehead of the vessel, a life size bust of the Queen, was found on the beach, and by his instructions was placed over the graves of four poor fellows who were buried on the island by their shipmates. Other relics such as the name board, life buoy etc, were brought to New Zealand. On board with "Derry Castle Limerick" painted on it, Captain Fairchild intends sending Home to the late owner of the vessel

The Otago Witness printed a number of images by Burton Bros  some before the figurehead was placed over the grave.
